threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: On the vicarious nature of anime/manga
threads.com:
More so than any other medium, anime and manga are crafted so towards their target consumer audience in a way that continually separates them from reality and enslaves them.
As Anno, Miyazaki, and other greats from previous generations have alluded to (even though they were not always correct in everything), there is a downward, ever-accelerating trend of anime and manga works being created by people who have experienced nothing but the anime and manga of their generation (including real-life experiences). This means that each generation, the "density" of the anime/manga quotient's exponent increments ever so insidiously.
But that is just a digression. The main point is that as a result, anime and manga are now essentially a digital drug, a virtual nanomachine virus spread through your screens, that segregate fans from reality. Any desires and necessities in real life (to make friends, engage in romantic relationships, pursue hobbies, chase dreams, work and earn money, exercise) are completely overwritten by the exact same but in vicarious fictional form.
Want to join a high school club? Watch K-On instead. Want a university romance? Watch Uzaki-chan instead. Want to change your career direction? Watch Aggretsuko instead to vent your work-related complaints. Feel like your life is missing something? Watch a nekketsu so it feels like you're accomplishing something along with the main character, or an isekai to feel like you already have it all (but still pretend to need to work hard). It won't do to belabor the point further.

I'll end on this. So what? What is there to be done? Commercialization is inevitable. While not everyone (even on /a/!) will fall into the hole of exclusive vicarious pleasure, many will. And many more will. A clear solution is not yet in sight. What would you suggest, anons? Personally, I believe one step forward could be to encourage people with more life experiences to pursue the industry instead of continuing the insular death spiral.

Ding Dong Circus by Sasaki Maki. Most Garo stuff is obscure, but Sasaki's works typically are surrealist with no narrative so I figure that turns off a lot of people. His artwork is amazing, and the guy did a jam page with Crumb. He eventually moved away from comics and was successful doing children's picture books instead.

>>245916242
Ryan Holmberg (who translated your image) has translated a ton of interesting manga, mostly Garo-related. I would say his Ten Cent Manga collections for Picturebox helped kick off the current alternative manga translation scene.
Some other publishers to watch for are Black Hook Press (on hiatus), Glacier Bay Books, Star Fruit Books, Breakdown Press, Last Gasp, and New York Review Comics.

>>245923015
To add a final note: the reason the second reset is different from the last, and the reason there's no precognition anymore, is that Pucci, the guy who was a firm believer in the existence of one fate, was actually "in the right" until the universe reset. Everything he did proved that his fate was to kill Jotaro and Jolyne and achieve MIH, which is why he was rewarded by being proven right with a universe where only his idea of one fate existed.
However, he wasn't satisfied and tried to paradox Emporio out of existence in the past, instead of just accepting his fate of escaping. So by doing this he ended up dying instead and actually changed fate for (his idea of) the worse, so no more Made In Heaven, because he was proven a hypocrite and undid his own ideals. It sounds retarded and it kind of is, but it's pretty well thought out in reality. Bravo Araki he never forgets.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>245922705
The Comic Book Crash occurred between 1993 and 1997, due in part to an over-saturation of "muh rare collectibles" (especially from Marvel & DC, with their holographic foil covers). Manga localizers resisted the urge to indulge in gimmicky variant covers, aside from Viz in the early-2000s. Since the late-90s, manga localizations have been confined to trade paperbacks, and flopping was largely abandoned after Tokyo Pop bucked the trend.
